subject: Fed's Clarida (voter) says global outlook has worsened since July meeting, but the US economy is in a good place right now; will act as appropriate to keep the economy in place
content:
• Disinflationary pressures and Global downturn show significant risks
  • Need to take into account where the economy is going in 2020 given the monetary policy lag
  • US data has been coming in well since the July FOMC meeting; some market indicators are pointing towards a recession but the Fed doesn't see one coming
  • Attributes global factors to the yield curve inversion, but will not ignore it
  • Takes impact of trade on the outlook as they come
  • Sees economic growth at or above trend growth in 2020

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 23rd August 2019: China retaliation sparks risk-off as market anticipates Trump response
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 23rd August 2019: China retaliation sparks risk-off as market anticipates Trump response

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities lower, Treasuries higher, Dollar lower, Crude lower

* REAR VIEW: China announces USD 75bln of tariffs on US goods; Trump demands US corporates to retreat from China; Powell walks a careful line

* ON MONDAY:  MON: UK Bank Holiday, German IFO, US Durables, Dallas Fed Manufacturing Business Index. TUE: German GDP (2nd), Hungarian Rate Decision, US House Price Index, S&P Case-Shiller, CB Consumer Confidence, Richmond Manufacturing Index. WED: GFK Consumer Climate, EZ M3 Money Supply, Israeli Rate Decision. THU: NZ ANZ Business Confidence, Australian CAPEX, German Import Prices, Norwegian GDP, German Labour Market Report, Eurozone Consumer Confidence, German CPI (final), US GDP (2nd), Good Trade Balance, Pending Home Sales. FRI: Tokyo CPI, Japanese Industrial Production, South Korean Rate Decision, Australian Building Approvals, German Retail Sales, Norwegian Labour Market Report, EZ CPI (flash), Italian CPI & GDP, US Personal Income & Spending, Core PCE Price Index, Canadian GDP, Chicago PMI, University of Michigan. (Click here for the full RANsquawk week in focus)

* CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: 23rd August 2019: REVIEWING Powell, Fed minutes, ECB minutes, RBA minutes; Previewing BOK. (Click here for the full RANsquawk central bank weekly)

 

* MARKET WRAP: Markets took a heavy risk off tone on Friday given the retaliatory China tariffs; US equity futures fell throughout the day which was further spurred by Trump stating he will announce his response ‘this afternoon’. Havens caught a bid with XAU sitting comfortably above 1500 heading into the weekend and USDJPY back below 105.50, and US 10y yields are now heading towards 1.50% which saw the 2s10s curve flirting with inversion throughout the tail end of the session. Participants are likely cautious ahead of trade risk and the G7 summit this weekend, where major assets are very much subject to headline risk.

* CHINA RETALIATES: Beijing announced it was slapping tariffs on USD 75bln of US goods at rates between 5% and 10%; China targets US ags sector, and autos, in response to the US’ moves to slap fresh tariffs on China in September and December (in two stages – China’s tariffs will also be implemented in two stages, on the same dates). Traders noted that the announcement was unexpected, and that is why markets reacted in a risk-off fashion, despite the size of the tariffs being eclipsed by the US’ measures. It was also a surprise given the positive comments on talks between the two nations made by NEC director Kudlow late on Thursday (where he said the two sides’ deputies had held a productive call, and there would be further talks ahead) and even White House Advisor Navarro (who on Friday stated the White House still expects talks will continue with China in September, and those talks will continue behind closed doors). Analysts at ING note that although China's tariffs are not comparable to the US', there are other measures Beijing can take to get back at the US; the nation has said, on a few occasions, that it has its own list of "unreliable entities", and there is some speculation that the first company to be included in that list will be a US corporate, which ING's warns could trigger an 'entity list' war, which will likely serve as another risk-off factor for risk assets. ING also speculated that the yuan could also play a role in China's response. One of the consequences is that China’s unexpected announcement has forced the US to take measures to retaliate, though the response may be interpreted as ‘unprepared’.

* TRUMP MEASURES: US President Trump announced he would be announcing the US’ retaliation to the China tariffs later Friday

* FED’S POWELL: The first thing to note about Fed chair Powell's remark is that they took note of Friday's trade escalations (which occurred hours before he was due to deliver his remarks at Jackson Hole), and the speech he did end up delivering, walked a careful line, to the extent that markets were relatively unchanged in the immediate aftermath of his comments; that in itself is particularly interesting, given that a consensus was developing ahead of the speech that Powell risked disappointing the dovish market expectations, with some suggesting that this outcome might have slammed risk assets. Powell acknowledged that fitting trade uncertainty into the Fed's policy framework was a challenge, noting that there were not precedent to guide its policy response in the current situation - some analysts said it implies that the FOMC might not use 'insurance' model of 1995 and 1998, where they fired three consecutive 25bps rate cuts. Powell also stated that the weeks since the July FOMC have been "eventful," and he has seen further evidence of a global slowdown (he cited Germany and China specifically, while also pointing to Hong Kong, Brexit, and political drama in Italy). "These factors are the reasons why the Fed eased in July, so the recent deterioration seems like a very strong hint that the Fed will ease again in September," Pantheon Macroeconomics said, despite some of the more hawkish Fed commentary that we have heard in the run up to Jackson Hole. Pantheon says sustained low inflation means that the near-term risks of the Fed responding to events are low, but note that the Chair pointed out that 'Inflation seems to be moving up closer to 2 percent', and that 'Because the most important effects of monetary policy are felt with uncertain lags of a year or more, the Committee must attempt to look through what may be passing developments and focus on things that seem likely to affect the outlook over time or that pose a material risk of doing so.'" In other words, Pantheon says, the Fed has room to move, but it cannot treat every ratcheting up of the trade war as reason to keep cutting rates without regard to the medium-term inflation picture. "We don’t envy Mr. Powell and his colleagues right now; all their analysis and forecasts can be upended by a single tweet, so the policymaking process has been wrecked, even without the overlay of the president railing at the Fed like Lear on the heath, but less coherently." Still, the consultancy argues that nothing in Powell's Jackson Hole speech suggests the Fed will pause in September. "The hawks have been vocal recently, but they seem still to be outnumbered. We expect a 25bp easing, and then a break in October, events permitting."

* BOE CARNEY: BoE Carney acknowledged that a no-deal has become more likely, but monetary policy is still undecided, where its path is still contingent on whether there is a deal or no-deal Brexit. The Governor said the UK Economy is operating just below potential with inflation just above target, where limited and gradual interest rate hikes will likely to be needed if there is a Brexit deal, where in his view monetary is easing would be more likely required in a no-deal. Carney acknowledged that surveys point to the UK economy stagnating in Q3; weak UK business investment is a warning to others of a potential impact of persistent trade tensions.

* CANADA JUNE RETAIL SALES: Retail Sales printed 0.0% M/M in June, slightly better than expectations for a decline of 0.1%. Core Retail Sales M/M rose by 0.9%, decent when compared with expectations for a decline. Both metrics saw the previous headlines revised lower by 0.1ppts each. Capital Economics notes that, in volume terms, retail sales increased by 0.4% GDP due to the rise in building material sales, which can feed into residential building construction for GDP; CapEco suggests that it signals that June’s GDP rose by 0.1%, instead of 0.0%. The consultancy noted that “consumer confidence was relatively high in July and suggests that retail sales growth should pick up in the coming months.”

* CRUDE WRAP: Energy markets are on the backfoot on Friday as China announced it would be targeting US crude oil in its latest tariffs with Trump tweeting some retaliatory punches, unsurprisingly WTI is taking the brunt of the hit where the Arb is widening from its recent lows. As a recap, Chinese imports of US crude oil for the January-June period were down 76.2% at 2.12mln tonnes (516k BPD), compared to the prior year, which is a drop in the water when compared to the 244.6mln tonnes of total crude oil China imported in the same period. Although China imports little US crude, mainly due to Chinese refiners preferring heavier crude grades and existing tensions deterring interest, the latest tariff move is spooking participants who fear this could be initial efforts as part of a wider Chinese effort to thwart US oil exports in addition to being a potential catalyst for a trade-war induced drop in global demand.

* TREASURIES WRAP: The TPLEX rallied higher in risk off flows on Friday, where China announcing fresh tariffs kicked off the move into Treasuries (and EGBs), before catching a second wave of inflows after US President Trump demanded via Twitter that US companies retreat from China and that his retaliation would be announced later on Friday. The mounting macro pessimism saw a clean march higher in the T-Note throughout the US session, where the short-end made its own headways, with the 2s10s flirting with inversion in the later session, exacerbating risk-off flows. At settlement, the curve was modestly inverted (2s10s -0.3bps), where the whole curve had seen yields fall between 8bps to 9bps.

* S&P 500 -2.6% AT 2847, NASDAQ-100 -3.2% AT 7465, DOW JONES -2.4% AT 25629. SECTORS: S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  -2.8%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples  -1.6%, S&P 500 Energy  -3.4%, S&P 500 Financials  -2.5%, S&P 500 Health Care  -2.3%, S&P 500 Industrials  -2.7%, S&P 500 Information Technology  -3.3%, S&P 500 Materials  -2.4%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  -2.6%, S&P 500 Utilities  -1.1%.a

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) managed to trade in the green despite the global sock rout, as reports suggested its 737 MAX jets could be back in operation as soon as October. Hasbro (HAS) was lower after it announced it is to acquire Entertainment One Ltd (ETO LN, ENTMF) for USD 4bln.

Earnings: Salesforce (CRM) & Intuit (INTU) outperformed today following strong earnings beats AMC on Thursday. On the flipside, Foot locker (FL) was hit after poor earnings which weighed on the retail sector as Nike (NKE) also fell on the report. Ross Stores (ROST) reported decent numbers, however was lower following EPS guidance slightly below expectations.  HP Inc (HPQ) suffered today - despite earnings beats - as it announced its CEO is to resign.

Tariffs: The tariffs spurred risk on flow which boosted gold well back above 1500 which boosted gold miners such as Newmont Goldcorp (NEM) & Barrick Gold (GOLD). The retaliatory tariffs specifically announced on automakers hurt the industry as Ford (F) and General Motors (GM) were lower by ~3%. The energy sector also took a hit as Crude oil is among the products tariffed at 5%.

* RUSSIA: Russian President Putin has ordered Russia's military to prepare measures in response to US missile tests, where he wants the military to take exhaustive measures to prepare for a reciprocal response; Putin caveated that Russia does not want to be drawn into an arms race.

* NORTH KOREA: North Korea’s Foreign Minister said US Secretary of State Pompeo casts dark shadows over talks with the US, adding that Pompeo is more interested in his political ambitions than US foreign policy and NK has given enough time to the US. The Foreign Minister also said NK is ready for both dialogue and confrontation, saying it would be a miscalculation if US continues with sanctions and that NK can remain the biggest threat to US for a long time.

* SOUTH KOREA/JAPAN: South Korea's Deputy National Security Advisor Kim said Japan has not only rejected, but ignored its offers for dialogue, saying this provides a chance to strengthen the South Korea-US alliance; coming after South Korea said on Thursday it would not renew the intelligence pact with Japan.

* FX WRAP:

* USD: The week in earnest was widely tipped to start on Wednesday via FOMC minutes, and the release did reveal some new policy insight as aside from the 2 known dissenters against any cut at all, some doves favoured 50 bp instead of the 25 bp insurance ease delivered. The minutes also divulged that the phrase mid-cycle adjustment used by Fed Chair Powell was not a personal remark but in the official account of July’s policy meeting and the net effect was a firmer Dollar on balance. However, the DXY recoiled to lows just the day after when Markit’s preliminary manufacturing PMI and the new orders sub-component both hit decade lows under 50 before paring losses ahead of the 98.000 level as Fed’s Harker chimed with typically hawkish comments from George (one of the aforementioned dissenting members along with Rosengren). The index subsequently scored a slender new high at 98.452 ahead of Powell at Jackson Hole, but eased back when China unveiled its retaliatory tariffs on USD 75 bln US goods and reinstated 25% on autos and auto parts. Back to the Fed chair, and his eagerly awaited address from the Central Bank event was actually relatively uneventful as the text maintained the act as appropriate to support economy mantra, but did not provide definitive pointers for September’s FOMC beyond acknowledging that a lot has happened since the previous meeting. Nevertheless, this prompted a volley of criticism from President Trump who promised action and more manoeuvres in the trade war against China, with the DXY now probing below 98.000 towards 97.50.

* GBP: The Pound is off best levels, but still on track for a stellar week with Cable ending the week at highs heading towards 1.23 from the 1.2065 lows and Eur/Gbp hugging the base of its 0.9030-0.9185 range. The main catalyst and bullish factor for Sterling, constructive soundbites from the EU and especially German Chancellor Merkel about the chances of reaching a ‘practical solution’ to the Irish border backstop issue that is compatible with the Good Friday Agreement and maintains the integrity of the single market. However, even the perceived more sceptical and rigid French President expressed confidence that a compromise can be found, but the task is for UK PM Johnson to come up with a viable alternative before October 31, of earlier (30 days was the timeframe set by Merkel, but realistically the 17-18 October EU Summit could be the deadline).

* EUR: Barring a minor breach and test of 1.1050, the single currency has displayed a very resilient streak above 1.1027 ytd lows after multiple tests of technical support around 1.1065 and is now back above 1.1100 ahead of next Tuesday’s Italian political party confab to try and form a new coalition Government. The Euro has also weathered more downbeat German growth outlooks and ECB minutes highlighting concerns about protracted downside economic risks with the aid of better than anticipated or feared preliminary PMIs.

* NZD/AUD/CAD: Contrasting fortunes for the non-US Dollars, with the Kiwi and Aussie switching places after respective manufacturing PMIs fell into contraction and Nzd/Usd and Aud/Usd both faith to keep hold and build on rebounds through 0.6400 and 0.6800. However, the major move and change in relative direction came after RBNZ Governor Orr ‘tweaked’ policy guidance to indicate a pause in September and reassessment in November based on the fact that the more aggressive ease at the last meeting to a 1% record OCR low allows time for contemplation. Elsewhere, strong/better than consensus Canadian data in the form of CPI and retail sales did little to stop the Loonie trading on overall swings in risk sentiment and a loose correlation with crude prices around the 1.3300 handle.

* CHF/JPY: Renewed and rising risk aversion prompted by the latest volley from China on tariffs and Trumps threat to hit back against Beijing (and the Fed) pushed the traditional safe-haven Franc, Yen and Gold to highs of circa 0.9740, 105.30 and 1530 that either constituted new or matched new pinnacles for the week following a bout of mainly tight/rangebound trade.

* EM: In stark contrast to the above, regional currencies succumbed to the broad and late downturn in sentiment with few exceptions aside from the Rand and Lira that were propped by specific and technical factors, with Usd/Cnh scaling 7.1000 that was crossed earlier in the week, but not convincingly amid speculation of Chinese bank intervention to curb Yuan depreciation.

BoE Carney says UK Economy is operating just below potential with inflation just above target, limited and gradual interest rate hikes likely to be needed if there is a Brexit deal and surveys point to the UK economy stagnating in Q3
content:
On Brexit

  • Likelihood of a No Deal Brexit has increased but it is not a given
  • Extended Brexit uncertainty could raise prospect of softer UK inflation and resurgent imported inflation
  • Ability of monetary policy to smooth a no deal Brexit hit would be constrained by the limits to MPC tolerance of above target inflation
  • After a no deal Brexit it is his personal view that easing monetary policy is more appropriate than not

On the economy

  • Underlying growth is likely positive, but muted
  • Weak UK business investment is a warning to others of a potential impact of persistent trade tensions

On policy

  • Policy uncertainty and protectionism could push down on global equilibrium interest rates and exacerbate concerns about monetary policy limits

analysis_details:
• This follows after China announced its plans to raise import tariff rates on some US goods; New tariff rates of 5-10% will apply to about USD 75bln worth of US goods on September 1st and December 15th, Crude oil will be among the products tariffed at 5% from September 1st

POTENTIAL TRUMP RESPONSE:

  • Tariff Roll-in: The US President could walk back on the tariff delay (i.e. some goods to be taxed on December 15th) which would mean 10% on the full batch of USD 300bln worth on September 1st. Although this seems to be unlikely as Trump preferably would want to keep goods prices down heading into the Christmas shopping season.
  • Tariff Ramp up: An increase of levy from 10% to 25% is nothing new. President Trump has threatened this a few times with the latest upon the announcement of the September 1st tariffs.
  • Currency War: Another highly touted move, Trump has constantly criticised the Fed for the reason behind a firmer Greenback, whilst also accusing China and Europe of manipulating its currencies. Many desks highlight that Trump could use the US Treasury Department’s Exchange Stability Fund to weaken the USD vs. the CNY.

subject: Fed Chair Powell says US economy is in a favourable place, Fed will act as appropriate, US economy is close to Fed’s goals, No recent precedents to guide policy response to trade uncertainty
content:
• There are, however, no recent precedents to guide any policy response to the current situation
  • Three factors that are weighing on this favorable outlook: slowing global growth, trade policy uncertainty, and muted inflation.
  • The three weeks since our July FOMC meeting have been eventful, beginning with the announcement of new tariffs on imports from China. We have seen further evidence of a global slowdown, notably in Germany and China.
  • Link to release

subject: Fed’s Mester (Non-voter, Hawk) says Chinese counter tariffs are just a continuation of the trade uncertainty that has been with us for some time; is undecided for Sept FOMC meeting
content:
On the domestic economy/rates:

  • Says the consumer is strong and the US economy is quite resilient

On the US vs its overseas competitors:

  • Says we are less exposed to trade tensions that Europe, says she is focused on consumer side of things when it comes to trade

China plans to raise import tariff rates on some US goods; New tariff rates of 5-10% will apply to about USD 75bln worth of US goods on September 1st and December 15th, Crude oil will be among the products tariffed at 5% from September 1st
content:
• Will be levied on 5078 products
  • China says it has to take countermeasures against US protectionism
  • China says it will resume additional tariffs on US autos (25%), and US auto parts
  • Are to impose extra 5% tariff on soy beans as of September 1st
  • Will impose extra 10% tariff on US wheat, corn, sorghum from December 15th
  • Will impose 10% on US beef and pork
reaction_details: • It was risk off in an immediate reaction to this news; ES Sep’ 19 futures fell to 2906 from 2932, 10 year UST Sep’ 9 futures rose to 130’10 from 130’02.
analysis_details:
• Note these dates from which the tariffs will be implemented are exactly in line with the dates when the US had been planning to implement its own tariffs on Chinese goods
  • Earlier, China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin says "Based on what I know, China will take further countermeasures in response to US tariffs on USD 300 billion Chinese goods. Beijing will soon unveil a plan of imposing retaliatory tariffs on certain US products."
  • Chinese imports for the January-June period were down 76.2% at 515,722 BPD, compared to the prior year

POTENTIAL TRUMP RESPONSE:

  • Tariff Roll-in: The US President could walk back on the tariff delay (i.e. some goods to be taxed on December 15th) which would mean 10% on the full batch of USD 300bln worth on September 1st. Although this seems to be unlikely as Trump preferably would want to keep goods prices down heading into the Christmas shopping season.
  • Tariff Ramp up: An increase of levy from 10% to 25% is nothing new. President Trump has threatened this a few times with the latest upon the announcement of the September 1st tariffs.
  • Currency War: Another highly touted move, Trump has constantly criticised the Fed for the reason behind a firmer Greenback, whilst also accusing China and Europe of manipulating its currencies. Many desks highlight that Trump could use the US Treasury Department’s Exchange Stability Fund to weaken the USD vs. the CNY.

Click here for further analysis

Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dove) refers to low inflation expectations as a reason to “get lower” in terms of rates; mentions yield curve inversion, says it is not a good place to be
content:
On domestic & global economy and its implication for rates;

  • Says consumption and labour market looks good, notes strong retail sales
  • Voices concern over global manufacturing contraction, wants to take out more insurance against the global downside risks,
  • Caveats that Fed could take back insurance cuts if economy improves next year
  • Refers to 1998 insurance cutting cycles (where 3 x 25bps cuts were made) as a good model for current situation, says he likes those examples and things were played very well

On Washington;

  • Says the deficit hawks in Washington are "on vacation"
  • When asked about US President Trump’s argument that US rates are high relative to Germany & other countries, says things are going well in US compared to Europe
  • When asked about US President Trump/Washington’s concern over a strong dollar, dismisses concerns about recent dollar strength

On financial stability;

  • Says he does not think there is an asset bubble like the previous 2007 housing or internet bubble

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 23rd August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer this morning in-line with the cautious gains overnight ahead of the main Jackson Hole event today of Fed’s Powell
  • USD is firmer vs most G10 counterparts particularly Sterling as backstop optimism fades, though NZD outperforms on RBNZ comments overnight
  • China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin says "Based on what I know, China will take further countermeasures in response to US tariffs on USD 300 billion Chinese goods. Beijing will soon unveil a plan of imposing retaliatory tariffs on certain US products."
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian Retail Sales, US New Home Sales, Fed’s Powell, Bullard, Mester, Kaplan & Harker & BoE’s Carney

JACKSON HOLE & G7 SCHEDULES

·        Schedule for both events

·        Jackson Hole & Recent Comments

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded with cautious gains as participants await Fed Chair Powell’s looming speech at the Jackson Hole Symposium and after the lack of conviction on Wall St. where risk appetite was dampened by hawkish Fed rhetoric, as well as decade-low US Manufacturing PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was positive with stock news in Australia dominated by earnings including Goodman Group and Sims Metals which have surged due to profit growth, although upside in the index was limited by weakness in the commodity sectors especially gold miners after the precious metal slipped below USD 1500/oz level. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was supported by favourable currency moves, while Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were higher despite early indecisiveness after China’s MOFCOM reiterated its threat to retaliate against the US in the trade dispute and amid mixed signals from the PBoC in which they conducted reverse repos but resulted to a net liquidity drain for the week and softened its reference rate, although not as weak as anticipated. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued amid similar weakness in T-notes and as stocks in the region eked mild gains, although downside was stemmed amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1.2tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos for a weekly net drain of CNY 30bln vs. last week's CNY 300bln injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0572 vs. Exp. 7.0674 (Prev. 7.0490)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the US is making pretty good progress in trade discussions with Japan regarding telecoms and agriculture, while there were separate comments from Japanese Economy Minister Motegi that they will resume ministerial level talks with US on trade today and are getting close to a conclusion. (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI (Jul) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Jul) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Jul) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

Sources close to US President Trump state that the White House is in a China bind, with a trade deal with China being 'tough to improbable' in the deteriorating environment., Axios

Subsequently, China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin says "Based on what I know, China will take further countermeasures in response to US tariffs on USD 300 billion Chinese goods. Beijing will soon unveil a plan of imposing retaliatory tariffs on certain US products. China has the ammunition to fight back, US side will feel the pain.” (Twitter)

US

US President Trump plans to pressure France to repeal new tax on US tech giants and will call for India to lower tariffs at the G7. In other news, White House will reportedly not move forward with plan to cut foreign aid by billions according to sources, although US Secretary of State Pompeo later stated that President Trump is still undecided on what to do. (Newswires/Politico)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said he thinks economy is strong and does not believe recession talk, while he added the US is still looking at tax cuts 2.0 which US President Trump has not taken off the table and just meant there won’t be anything immediate. Kudlow also suggested there could be tax cuts before 2020 election and that short-term payroll tax cut is unlikely although personal rates could be lowered, and capital gains tax could be reduced. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter. Dove) noted that global growth risks and trade uncertainty could result to a rate cut. (Newswires/WSJ)

GEOPOLITICS

Russian President Putin has ordered Russia's military to prepare measures in response to US missile tests, Putin wants the military to take exhaustive measures to prepare for a reciprocal response, according to Russia's Kremlin. Adding that Russia does not want to be drawn into a arms race. (Newswires)

North Korea Foreign Minister Ri said US Secretary of State Pompeo casts dark shadows over US-North Korea talks and that Pompeo is more interested in his political ambitions than US foreign policy, while the Foreign Minister added we have given enough time to US and are ready for both dialogue and confrontation, while he added it would be a miscalculation if US continues with sanctions and that North Korea can remain the biggest threat to US for a long time. (KCNA)

Russian Finance Ministry said Russia is "actively considering" issuing Yuan-denominated bonds on the Moscow Exchange; Sputnik

South Korea's Deputy National Security Advisor Kim says Japan has not only rejected but ignored their offers for a dialogue, provides a chance to strengthen South Korea/US alliance. (Newswires)

Ireland will look to block its free trade deal between the EU and South American trade bloc unless Brazil takes action to protect the Amazon rainforest. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Tory Remainers who are intent on stopping a no-deal are reportedly attempting to delay Brexit by preparing to hold their own talks with Brussels, sources state. A Downing Street source added that Brussels could reject any request for an extension, even if PM Johnson is legally bound to ask for one. (Times) 

Remain rebels in the UK Conservative party have delayed their attempt to force PM Johnson to abandon a No-deal Brexit amid disagreement with MPs in other parties on when to act. (The Sun)

EU officials want to set up a EUR 100bln wealth fund to bolster "European champions" against American and Chinese business rivals like Google, Apple and Alibaba. (Politico)

German Finance Ministry spokeswoman says it is now time to use "cleverer methods" to ensure the German economy grows, adds that Germany is not in a recession. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities opened and remained on a somewhat firmer footing (thus far) [Eurostoxx 50 +0.3%] on the last trading day of the week which follows on from an initially cautious Asia-Pac session before sentiment turned for the better ahead of Fed Chair Powell’s opening remarks at the Jackson Hole Symposium at 1500BST/1000EDT. Sectors are mostly in the green with the exception of the energy sector which coincides with recent losses in the oil complex. Meanwhile, the IT sector outperforms as stellar earnings from US-listed Salesforce.com (+6.8% pre-market) provided tailwinds to DAX heavyweight SAP (+0.6%), which accounts for around 1.5% of the Stoxx 600 index. In terms of individual movers, Thyssenkrupp (+0.7%) opened higher amid source reports that it is planning to merge its steel unit with Klöckner (+8.3%). Also, it’s worth keeping in mind a report by Politico which stated that EU Officials are seeking to create a EUR 100bln wealth fund in order to bolster ‘European Champions’ against American and Chinese business rivals such as Apple (+0.6% pre-market), Google (+0.9% pre-market) and Alibaba (+0.9% premarket).

FX

 

USD - The Greenback has nudged up a bit further from post-US manufacturing PMI lows that saw the DXY skirt 98.000, and the index is now edging back up towards wtd peaks just shy of 98.500 posted on Tuesday within a 98.185-436 range. Relatively hawkish rhetoric from Fed’s George and Harker have underpinned the Buck ahead of Chair Powell’s keynote speech that is being eyed for clearer policy guidance given this week’s FOMC minutes highlighting divisions between voters beyond the 2 dissenters against July’s 25 bp insurance/mid-cycle rate cut.

NZD/GBP - Not quite all change, but positions and roles have partially reversed for the Kiwi and Pound following supportive comments from RBNZ Governor Orr and less euphoria/hype about the prospect of formulating a plan for the Irish backstop that is mutually acceptable for the UK and EU. To recap, NZ’s Central Bank head indicated that the recent larger than expected OCR ease (1/2 point) affords some time for assessment before deciding whether more stimulus is needed in November and effectively signally a pause next month, while French President Macron and German Chancellor Merkel have both been receptive to PM Johnson and the notion that a resolution to the Irish backstop impasse can be reached before it’s too late, but the ball and onus to come up with something different is back in UK hands. In response, Nzd/Usd has rebounded towards 0.6400, with AUD/Nzd back under 1.0600 as Aud/Usd pivots 0.6750 amidst the ongoing, incremental rise Usd/Cny mid-point rates, while Cable has retraced more of its gains through 1.2200 at one stage.

CHF/JPY - The Franc and Yen are both weaker vs the Dollar as US Treasury yields rise and the curve steepens, while safe-haven demand is also waning with global trade and geopolitical tensions still prevalent, but not escalating (at present). As such, Usd/Chf and Usd/Jpy are firmer around 0.9850 and 106.50 handles respectively.

CAD/EUR - The Loonie and Euro remain relatively rangebound vs the Greenback circa 1.3315 and 1.1065, with the former looking for more independent inspiration from Canadian retail sales data after failing to glean any real or lasting impetus via firm CPI and other minor macro inputs this week (wholesale trade and manufacturing sales). Meanwhile, the single currency is hanging on above 1.1050 and the 2019 base (1.1029) awaiting insight from Fed’s Powell, September’s ECB policy meeting to see how much stimulus is delivered after minutes underlining heightened economic concerns and what happens next in Italy on the political front.

EM - The Rand is outperforming and clawing back recent losses vs the Buck with a less downbeat/negative take from Moody’s on the SA fiscal outlook following extra financial assistance for Eskom helping alongside a less bearish technical backdrop as Usd/Zar reverses through 15.2500 and 15.1500 before basing around 15.1300.

RBNZ Governor Orr reiterated a rate cut earlier reduces likelihood of having to do more later and stated they will do whatever it takes to support New Zealand economy but can afford to wait and observe what is happening, while he added that they will see what the situation is like in November and will cut if necessary. (Newswires)

FIXED

Some consolidation, short covering and perhaps even dip buying after the early sell-off fuelled by deeper losses in UK bonds on the back of renewed Brexit deal hopes. However, Gilts are still markedly lagging around 133.55 within 133.84-38 parameters vs Bunds that have bounced off 177.48 lows towards 178.00 and US Treasuries reclaiming 130-00, albeit still soft and re-steepening. As noted and widely regarded, Fed’s Powell is expected to headline Friday’s agenda, but breaking news will be a factor and on that note latest comments from Russia and reports on US-China trade look rather risk-off.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are choppy in a relatively tight parameter as all eyes turn to Fed Chair Powell for any hint on the magnitude of the widely anticipated Fed rate cut in September against the backdrop of some recent hawkish Fed rhetoric. WTI futures remain contained in a 55.20-60/bbl range whilst its Brent counterpart straddles on either side of 60/bbl. Elsewhere, gold is marginally softer intraday and remains below the 1500/oz mark, largely weighed on by a firmer Greenback, in anticipation for the Fed Chair’s speech. Copper on the other hand is rebounding off recent lows, albeit prices remain below 2.6/lb with desks citing US-China optimism as a driver, although a retracement of recent losses/some profit taking may also be factors. Meanwhile, Dalian iron ore surged over 3% overnight following the ruthless sell-off in recent days, also potentially due to profit-taking heading into a risk-packed weekend. Finally, ING notes that the recent surge in Nickel prices seem to be running out of steam after prices declined around 4% this week. “The speculated supply disruptions from Indonesia have not materialised yet, whilst the demand-side continues to face pressure as margins for stainless steel producers take a hit” the analysts state.

subject: China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin says "Based on what I know, China will take further countermeasures in response to US tariffs on USD 300 billion Chinese goods. Beijing will soon unveil a plan of imposing retaliatory tariffs on certain US products."
content:
• Adds, "China has ammunition to fight back. The US side will feel the pain."
  • Click here for link
reaction_details: • Modest downside in equity futures and upticks in core bonds coincided with the tweet
analysis_details:
• Yesterday, Chinese Commerce Ministry said China will have to retaliate if US persists on current course, adding that any new measures will lead to escalation, declines to comment on possible retaliatory measures, will publish unreliable entity list soon
  • This comes ahead of the 10% US levy on part of USD 300bln worth of Chinese goods effective September 1st

POSSIBLE CHINA RETALIATION:

  • Tariff Increase: China has currently taxed USD 110bln worth of US goods at a range of 20-25%. This levy could increase further to match the effect of US’ tax imposition on the outstanding goods, albeit the size of the goods US affected is likely to remain as US imports far more goods from China than vice versa.
  • An unreliable entity list: This list could exclude some US firms from doing business with Chinese companies.
  • Rare-earth restrictions: Another “weapon” in China’s arsenal. Prohibiting these rare earth exports to the US will significantly affect the hi-tech/electronic producers which may be forced to slow or even halt some US production. SCMP reported earlier this month that China’s rare earth producers are ready to weaponise their supply control and pass any tariffs as costs to US customers.
  • Yuan: The Chinese currency weakened last week to above 7.00 against the USD, for the first time in a decade, after the US' latest escalation of trade wars. The move higher resulted in a significant risk-off reaction in markets. The PBOC's response was somewhat predictable (China will not participate in competitive devaluation of the Yuan, although the currency move prompted the US to label China as a 'currency manipulator' by the US). Despite this, the daily USD/CNY fixing has been creeping higher (ex-last two days), whilst PBoC officials kept reiterating that the Yuan is at an appropriate level at present.

subject: Nomura Quants: Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole meeting will determine global macro hedge fund sentiment in the near term.
content:
• Nomura note that, based on the US equity exposure at major hedge funds, much of the recent dip-buying appears to have come from the global macro hedge funds, whose bullish stance on US equities since July seems rooted in the unexpected strength of recent macroeconomic indicators, best seen in an improvement in the US macro surprise index.
  • However, the bank sees much of the recent upswing in economic indicators in summer (July through early September) as seasonal in nature. “If US indicators follow past patterns and begin to turn downward next week” the bank notes “stock buying by global macro hedge funds could hit a ceiling and begin to decline.” As such, should the data take a turn for the worse, the bank suggests that further good news, perhaps in the form of a series of Fed rate cuts of between 50-100bps, is a prerequisite for keeping global macro hedge funds bullish, and avoiding a second sharp drop in global equity prices.
  • Looking at systematic players such as CTAs; Nomura note that their positions in US equities tend not to stray too far from US economic trends, as such, the possibility that CTAs could switch to shorting futures to a small degree after closing out long positions on futures, should August’s ISM Index print in line with expectations at 51.0. The bank observes that CTAs appear to have closed out only around 60% of long positions on futures so far; as such, further systematic (and one-sided) selling pressure on equities remains a possibility. Algo players will be inclined to sell equity and buy bonds, it suggests.
  • Should Fed Chair Powell's speech provide a positive catalyst to fundamentals investors such as global macro hedge funds, they may be inclined to expand their US equities purchases. 2,960 for the S&P 500 and 7,720 for the Nasdaq 100 are key breakeven levels for CTAs, and given their above noted possible inclination to sell equities, whether or not futures can rally past this point may be a key “watershed moment” in determining the supremacy of algo players versus human traders.

content: It remains to be seen whether goodwill and well meaning words translate to anything tangible in the next month or even October 31, but for now it seems that UK markets are taking comments from 2 of the EU’s top officials (Merkel and Macron) in good faith and factoring in some form of alternative arrangement for the Irish border that will facilitate a Brexit deal. Indeed, the 10 year benchmark has retreated further from this week’s recovery highs, with stops said to have been tripped when an earlier August low was breached (133.73) and more once 133.65 also gave way. Gilts have subsequently been down to 133.38 and just a handful of ticks away from the next downside chart/technical target at 133.33 – this month’s base – and for once, or rather unusually it appears that contagion has spread to Bunds and US Treasuries, as the former slides to 177.48 and latter through 130-00. Similarly, the 3 month strip is towards the bottom end of the early -0.5 to -3.5 tick Liffe range.

content: In keeping with this week’s overall trend, upticks in the core Eurozone bond continue to be faded and the latest attempt to rally topped out at 178.10 compared to Thursday’s Eurex close. However, the 10 year German benchmark has not breached yesterday’s low that coincides with a technical support area and is close to the psychological -60 bp mark in cash terms having pared losses from a 177.74 low, and Bunds could well remain largely contained until Friday’s headline event in the form of Fed chair Powell’s speech from Jackson Hole that is due to kick off at 15.00BST. Comments in the run up by several other Fed members may provide some interim/passing interest and price ‘action’, but the next major moves and direction for debt and the curves appear mainly if not entirely down to Powell.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 23rd August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded with cautious gains as participants await Fed Chair Powell’s speech and after the lack of conviction on Wall St.
  • In FX markets, the greenback extended above the 98.00 level, EUR/USD was contained in a tight range, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses edged mild gains and NZD/USD firmed after comments from RBNZ Governor Orr
  • UK Tory Remainers who are intent on stopping a no-deal are reportedly attempting to delay Brexit, according to sources
  • Italian President Mattarella stated consultations will be held on Tuesday on forming a new government, 5-Star lawmakers are backing talks with the PD Party
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian Retail Sales, US New Home Sales, Fed’s Powell, Bullard, Mester, Kaplan & Harker, BoE’s Carney

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded with cautious gains as participants await Fed Chair Powell’s looming speech at the Jackson Hole Symposium and after the lack of conviction on Wall St. where risk appetite was dampened by hawkish Fed rhetoric, as well as decade-low US Manufacturing PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was positive with stock news in Australia dominated by earnings including Goodman Group and Sims Metals which have surged due to profit growth, although upside in the index was limited by weakness in the commodity sectors especially gold miners after the precious metal slipped below USD 1500/oz level. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was supported by favourable currency moves, while Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were higher despite early indecisiveness after China’s MOFCOM reiterated its threat to retaliate against the US in the trade dispute and amid mixed signals from the PBoC in which they conducted reverse repos but resulted to a net liquidity drain for the week and softened its reference rate, although not as weak as anticipated. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued amid similar weakness in T-notes and as stocks in the region eked mild gains, although downside was stemmed amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for over JPY 1.2tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos for a weekly net drain of CNY 30bln vs. last week's CNY 300bln injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0572 vs. Exp. 7.0674 (Prev. 7.0490)

China Global Times Editor said US tried to suppress China, but the damage caused is less than what China had feared. (Twitter)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the US is making pretty good progress in trade discussions with Japan regarding telecoms and agriculture, while there were separate comments from Japanese Economy Minister Motegi that they will resume ministerial level talks with US on trade today and are getting close to a conclusion. (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI (Jul) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Jul) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Jul) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%) 

 

UK/EU

UK Tory Remainers who are intent on stopping a no-deal are reportedly attempting to delay Brexit by preparing to hold their own talks with Brussels, sources state. A Downing Street source added that Brussels could reject any request for an extension, even if PM Johnson is legally bound to ask for one. (Times)

Remain rebels in the UK Conservative party have delayed their attempt to force PM Johnson to abandon a No-deal Brexit amid disagreement with MPs in other parties on when to act. (The Sun)

Italian President Mattarella said new elections is a choice that cannot be taken lightly and that some parties he has spoken to said they are working towards a deal to create a coalition but needed more time which he will give. Furthermore, Mattarella also stated new consultations will be held on Tuesday, while Italian 5-Star Leader Di Maio is said to have handed Mattarella ten reforms that need passing before parliament can be dissolved. Meanwhile, 5-Star lawmakers stated that they back talks with PD on a new government. League Leader Salvini also stated that he is willing to re-form a government with 5-Star if it adopts a more constructive attitude to the League’s policies. (Newswires)

EU officials want to set up a EUR 100bln wealth fund to bolster "European champions" against American and Chinese business rivals like Google, Apple and Alibaba. (Politico)

 

FX

In FX markets, the greenback extended above the 98.00 level and is more determined in comparison to the choppy trade seen in the prior session where turbulence was triggered by opposing factors including hawkish Fed comments and disappointing PMI data. EUR/USD was contained in a tight range at the 1.1000 handle after the ECB minutes noted the slowdown is more protracted than previously thought and amid ongoing political uncertainty in Italy where parties have several days to attempt to form a government, while Deputy PM Salvini appeared to have changed his tune and suggested the League are still willing to re-form a government with 5-Star if it is more constructive. GBP/USD slightly pulled back but remained above 1.2200 after German Chancellor Merkel once again spurred the currency with her optimism regarding reaching a solution by the Brexit date despite contrasting views from within her close circle. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses edged mild gains and another leg in this week’s price swings, while NZD/USD firmed after comments from RBNZ Governor Orr that they will do whatever it takes to support New Zealand economy but can afford to wait and observe what is happening. Furthermore, Orr stated they will see what the situation is like in November and will cut if necessary, which suggests a move in the September meeting is unlikely, while a breakdown of support around 1.0600 in AUD/NZD added to the outperformance of NZD against its trans-Tasman counterpart.

RBNZ Governor Orr reiterated a rate cut earlier reduces likelihood of having to do more later and stated they will do whatever it takes to support New Zealand economy but can afford to wait and observe what is happening, while he added that they will see what the situation is like in November and will cut if necessary. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued with WTI crude futures unchanged amid a lack of fresh catalysts overnight and with market participants tentative ahead of Fed Chair Powell’s speech at the Jackson Hole symposium. Elsewhere, gold prices are marginally lower after having recently given up the USD 1500/oz level with the precious metal hampered by a firmer greenback following the recent hawkish Fed rhetoric, while copper prices flatlined amid the cautious tone in the region.

 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea Foreign Minister Ri said US Secretary of State Pompeo casts dark shadows over US-North Korea talks and that Pompeo is more interested in his political ambitions than US foreign policy, while the Foreign Minister added we have given enough time to US and are ready for both dialogue and confrontation, while he added it would be a miscalculation if US continues with sanctions and that North Korea can remain the biggest threat to US for a long time. (KCNA)

 

US

Major curve spreads were mixed at settlement, although +/- 1bps or so vs Wednesday’s settlement levels. There was a steepening bias in early trade, however, underpinned by the ‘hawkish’ FOMC meeting minutes. A little bit of indecision has been seen in Thursday trade, with traders questioning if Powell will be able to deliver on the market’s dovish expectations. In pre-market US trade, Treasuries moves in sympathy with Bunds. However, the focus was back on Fed officials after remarks from Fed’s hawkish voter (dissenter) George, as well as somewhat hawkish comments from the Fed’s Harker; the net impact of these was for risk assets to come under pressure. Focus now on Powell, with risks of a disappointment.  US T-note futures (U9) settled 7+ ticks lower at 130-09+.

US President Trump plans to pressure France to repeal new tax on US tech giants and will call for India to lower tariffs at the G7. In other news, White House will reportedly not move forward with plan to cut foreign aid by billions according to sources, although US Secretary of State Pompeo later stated that President Trump is still undecided on what to do. (Newswires/Politico)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said he thinks economy is strong and does not believe recession talk, while he added the US is still looking at tax cuts 2.0 which US President Trump has not taken off the table and just meant there won’t be anything immediate. Kudlow also suggested there could be tax cuts before 2020 election and that short-term payroll tax cut is unlikely although personal rates could be lowered, and capital gains tax could be reduced. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter. Dove) said he was in favour of the rate cut in July as the Fed has to be forward looking and that his expectations for growth are about 2% with risks tilted to the downside but added as long as consumers stays strong, we will have solid growth. Kaplan also stated he is taking time to assess all incoming data ahead of September FOMC and would like to avoid taking further action on rates although separately noted that global growth risks and trade uncertainty could result to a rate cut. (Newswires/WSJ)

subject: Italy's Deputy PM Di Maio (5-Star), when asked about the proposal to cut the number of lawmakers, says the cuts cannot wait
analysis_details:
• Note: Previously, Salvini proposed accepting 5SM's demand for a parliamentary reform in return for swift elections, a measure seen as an olive branch to progress proceedings; the proposal will see the number of MPs in both houses cut from 945 to 600; this has been approved by parliament on three occasions, with the fourth vote due in September. 
  • HSBC says that completing this reform would mean elections could not take place for another five to six months at least, due to the need to allow a possible referendum to be called, and to re-draw the electoral boundaries.
